author: JuliaRegistrator

comments.body:
Your `new package` pull request met all of the guidelines for auto-merging and is scheduled to be merged when the mandatory waiting period (3 days) has elapsed.

Since you are registering a new package, please make sure that you have read the package naming guidelines: https://pkgdocs.julialang.org/v1/creating-packages/#Package-naming-guidelines



---
If you want to prevent this pull request from being auto-merged, simply leave a comment. If you want to post a comment without blocking auto-merging, you must include the text `[noblock]` in your comment. You can edit blocking comments, adding `[noblock]` to them in order to unblock auto-merging.
<!-- [noblock] -->
<!---
this_is_the_single_automerge_comment
--->

Can you give some background on this? It's a bit of an unusual monorepo setup…

The repo description says "Temporary repository to hold BinaryBuilder rewrite". Is it intentional / a good idea to register new packages from a "temporary" location?

Would it be possible to add a README to the repository to give a bit of explanation for people stumbling across it?

Normally, for new registrations, I would ask that packages have at least minimal README. Even if they're secondary/extension packages, the README should still give a paragraph of context for the package, and link to the documentation of the main package. In this case, BinaryBuilder already has great documentation at https://binarybuilder.org. But I still think it would be a good idea to add README (also for how the package might show up on JuliaHub?)

(I'm just blocking this temporarily to give @staticfloat a chance to confirm; this is not an objection)

[noblock]

Those are very fair points.  I've added `README.md` files to all subpackages and for the `BB2.jl` repository overall.

The background is that this repository is a complete rewrite of `BinaryBuilder.jl`, and while I originally thought that I would eventually replace `BinaryBuilder.jl` with this new code and release a breaking version of `BinaryBuilder.jl` with the new code, I now think that we're going to need to maintain the old `BinaryBuilder.jl` for a while, and so it's probably best to just have them as two separate packages.  Therefore, I have taken away the "temporary" from the repository description.

As part of the rewrite process, I am factoring out many pieces of functionality into their own sub-packages for maintainability, package precompilation/load time, and ecosystem-reuse reasons.  However it's still very convenient to be able to co-develop all the packages, hence the monorepo setup.

This leaves open the question, should I re-name the repository to `BinaryBuilder2.jl`, or just continue to leave it as `BB2.jl`?  I don't have a strong opinion, but if I should rename it then I should do it now before I start registering all of those subpackages.

> Should I re-name the repository to BinaryBuilder2.jl

Seems to me like that would be the right thing to do, but I don't have any strong preferences around this. Maybe solicit some feedback on Slack or Discourse?

> if I should rename it then I should do it now

Right… [your own comment](https://github.com/JuliaRegistries/General/pull/103889#issuecomment-2029187643) is now blocking, so I'll unblock [mine](https://github.com/JuliaRegistries/General/pull/103889#issuecomment-2028802046), and you can make your own decision.

[noblock]
I decided to rename it to `BinaryBuilder2.jl`.  Registrator made a new PR: https://github.com/JuliaRegistries/General/pull/104019
Sounds good! I also pinged the Slack in `#pkg-registration` about https://github.com/JuliaRegistries/General/pull/104021

title: New package: BinaryBuilderPlatformExtensions v0.1.0
